name: preserved
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
past simple and past participle of
preserve
B2 to keep something as it is, especially in order to prevent it from decaying or being damaged or destroyed: to preserve the environment We want to preserve the character of the town while improving the facilities. The agreement preserved our right to limit trade in endangered species. Putting varnish on wood is a way of preserving it. I need to get out of the house from time to time just to preserve (= prevent me from losing) my sanity. See also
well preserved
to treat food in a particular way so that it can be kept for a long time without going bad: preserved fruit oranges preserved in brandy
More examplesFewer examplesIt's our duty to preserve the planet for future generations.The Forestry Commission is responsible for preserving over 2 million acres of woodland.The remains of the Roman fort are well preserved.Every attempt is being made to ensure that these works of art are preserved for posterity.He has a collection of prehistoric insects preserved in amber.
